The promotional roles of multivalent metal ions and oxygen vacancies on nitrogen-doped carbon-combined CuMn-based catalysts for cyclohexylbenzene oxidation Yanlin Xiao Investigation Writing – original draft Zihang Wang Investigation Methodology Guoli Fan Visualization Formal analysis Feng Li Conceptualization Writing – review & editing ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology Beijing 100029 China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing, 100029, China. ⁎ Corresponding author. In this work, we fabricated nitrogen-doped carbon (NC)-combined CuMn-based catalysts derived from layered double hydroxide and melamine mixture precursor and further explored their activity in the aerobic oxidation of cyclohexylbenzene (CHB) to produce cyclohexylbenzene-1-hydroperoxide (CHBHP) using molecular oxygen as the oxidant. Series of structural characterizations demonstrated that multivalent Cu and Mn species and abundant surface defective oxygen vacancies could form in catalysts, due to comprehensive redox processes between Cu and Mn atoms upon high-temperature calcination of precursors under inert atmosphere, as well as the promotional effect of melamine added on the reduction of metal ions. As-fabricated NC-combined CuMn catalyst bearing a 1:1 Cu:Mn molar ratio showed a higher catalytic oxidation activity, in comparison to other NC-decorated CuMn-based catalysts, NC-free CuMn-based one, and pure single metal oxides (i.e., CuO, MnO2). It was revealed that the presence of favorable multivalent Cu and Mn ions and abundant oxygen vacancies was conducive to the effective adsorption and activation of CHB and oxygen molecules, thus accelerating the selective oxidation of CHB to form CHBHP. Moreover, surface NC overlayer on catalysts could protect surface structures of catalysts during the oxidation. The present study provides deep understanding of the roles of surface-active metal species and oxygen vacancies of CuMn-based catalysts for efficient oxidation of CHB to form CHBHP. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords CuMn-based catalyst Multivalent metal species Nitrogen-doped carbon layer Surface oxygen vacancies Aerobic oxidation of cyclohexylbenzene Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Phenol, as one of the most important chemical intermediates, is widely utilized to produce numerous compounds including dyes, perfumes, resins, pharmaceuticals, and other chemicals [1]. Currently, the Hock process is a well-established commercial technique to produce phenol in the whole world [2–4]. Herein, cumene can be oxidized by molecular oxygen to form the corresponding hydroperoxide, followed by an acid-catalyzed decomposition to attain phenol. However, the coproduction of a large amount of acetone reduces its economic attractiveness in the chemical industry. Recently, an alternative route to produce phenol involving the oxidation of cyclohexylbenzene (CHB) to produce cyclohexylbenzene-1-hydroperoxide (CHBHP) and further decomposition of tertiary hydroperoxide has been developed [5,6]. Meanwhile, cyclohexanone as the coproduct can be utilized as the solvent or as the intermediate for the synthesis of caprolactam and nylon. Additionally, cyclohexanone can be further converted into phenol through the dehydrogenation process. Therefore, the peroxidation of CHB to produce phenol is an atom-economic and green process with attractive industrial application prospects. Previously, it was reported that the oxidation of CHB to CHBHP could well proceed using N-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI) as the homogenous catalyst and CHBHP itself as the initiator [5]. In this case, NHPI could promote the hydrogen abstraction from the 1-position in the cyclohexyl ring of CHB, thus accelerating the oxidation reaction. Despite its high catalytic efficiency, several disadvantages of NHPI including high cost and the difficulty in the recovery and reuse limit its large-scale industrial application. As we know, transition metal oxides are commonly used in many heterogeneous oxidation processes [7–9], due to their capabilities for chain initiation and reaction acceleration. In recent years, few studies on the heterogeneous catalytic oxidation of CHB and the further acid-catalyzed hydrolysis to produce phenol and cyclohexanone have been reported [10–12]. In the cases of single metal oxide catalysts (i.e., CuO, MnO2), however, there are some disadvantages of low catalytic activity. Despite above problems, the instinct character of heterogeneous catalysts including easy separation and recovery, relatively low cost, and good stability provides potential and promising opportunities for their development in the oxidation of CHB. Therefore, it is urgent to develop new and stable heterogeneous catalyst systems for the efficient peroxidation of CHB. As one of the most important two-dimensional inorganic compounds, layered double hydroxides (LDHs) contains tunable bivalent and trivalent metal cations located within the brucite-like layers [13,14]. Accordingly, stable, highly dispersive, and uniform mixed metal oxides (MMOs) can be formed through high-temperature transformation of LDH precursors [15]. For instance, recently, we have reported alumina-supported cobalt- and CoCu-based metal oxide catalysts derived from CoZnAl-LDH and CoCuAl-LDH precursors for the oxidation of ethylbenzene to acetophenone using tert-butyl hydroperoxide as the oxidant [16,17], which exhibited much better catalytic performance than other supported catalysts prepared by conventional incipient impregnation, due to the highly dispersive feature of active species and the synergistic effect between metal species. On the other hand, it also was reported that nitrogen-doped carbon (NC) could greatly regulate electronic structures of carbon materials [18,19], thus making them an ideal additive in supported catalysts [20–23]. Moreover, strong electronic interactions or geometric effect between active species (or particles) and the surface NC layer can significantly improve the stability of resulting NC-doped catalysts. Therefore, inspired by above-mentioned studies on the oxidation of CHB using single metal oxides, it is hypothesized that by the introduction of two active metal Cu and Mn cations into the brucite-like lattice of LDH precursors, resulting MMOs containing Cu and Mn species will be appropriate to construct Cu-Mn bimetal catalysts with tunable surface compositions and structures applied in the oxidation of CHB. Further, the combination of LDH and melamine may modify the chemical states of active metals of resulting MMOs through the reducibility of NC component and improve the stability of catalysts. In this present work, we fabricated NC-combined CuMn-based catalysts (NC-CuMn) through the thermal decomposition of the mixture of ternary CuMnAl-LDH and melamine ( Scheme 1) and explored their performance in the aerobic oxidation of CHB to produce CHBHP using molecular oxygen. It was found that the combination of melamine with CuMnAl-LDH precursors could result in the formation of multivalent Cu (i.e., Cu0, Cu+, Cu2+) and Mn (i.e., Mn2+, Mn3+, Mn4+) species and NC component in catalysts upon high-temperature calcination under inert atmosphere, as well as the generation of abundant surface oxygen vacancies. It was shown that as-formed NC-CuMn catalyst bearing a 1:1 Cu:Mn molar ratio exhibited a better catalytic performance with a CHBHP yield of 16.5 %, compared to other NC-CuMn catalysts, NC-free one, and single metal oxides (i.e., CuO, MnO2). Up to now, no study on bimetallic CuMn-based catalysts for the peroxidation of CHB to produce CHBHP is reported. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Ternary CuMnAl-LDH precursors were synthesized by a coprecipitation approach. Typically, Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O, Mn(CH3COO)2·4 H2O, Al(NO3)3 ·9 H2O (0.1 M) were dissolved in 50 mL deionized water to form a salt solution with a fixed 3:1 (Cu+Mn): Al molar ratio, while Na2CO3 (0.2 M) and NaOH (0.48 M) were added into 50 mL deionized water to get a base mixed solution. Then, above two solutions were slowly dropped into a four-necked flask with 50 mL of deionized water under vigorous agitation to keep a constant pH value of about 10. Subsequently, the resulting suspension was aged at 60 °C for 6 h. After centrifugation, the precipitate was washed with deionized water for more than five times and dried at 70 °C for 12 h. The obtained LDH sample was denoted as CuMnAl-LDH-x, where the Cu:(Cu+Mn) molar ratio is set at x:3 (x = 1, 1.5, 2). Further, CuMnAl-LDH/melamine mixture with the 1:1 mass ratio was calcined under N2 flow at 550 °C for 4 h to obtain NC-CuMnO-x sample. In addition, CuMnAl-LDH-1.5 sample was also calcined according to the above same procedure to obtain CuMnO-1.5 without the addition of melamine. And, pristine g-C3N4 was prepared by calcination of melamine under N2 flow at 550 °C for 4 h. 2.2 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurement was conducted on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer using the Cu Kα radiation. Contents of metal elements were quantitatively analyzed by an inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES) using nitrohydrochloric acid to dissolve samples. Contents of nitrogen and carbon were analyzed by an Elementar Vario elemental analyzer. Nitrogen adsorption experiments were performed on ASAP 2020 sorptometer apparatus (Micromeritics). The specific surface area was calculated by the Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) method. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images were collected on JEOL 2100 transmission electron microscope. High-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM-energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (HAADF-STEM-EDX) images were taken from JEOL2010F instrument. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra was attained on a Bruker ESP300E spectrometer at room temperature. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out on a Micromeritics ChemiSorb 2920 instrument with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) and X-ray-induced Auger electron spectra (XAES) were collected on Thermo VG ESCALAB250 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer using the Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV photons). All of the binding energies were corrected by the C 1 s binding energy of 284.6 eV. CHB temperature-programmed desorption (CHB-TPD) were performed on Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920. Before characterization, the sample (100 mg) was immersed into a dichloromethane solution containing CHB for two days. Afterwards, the sample was pretreated under Ar flow at 25 ℃ for 1 h and heated from the 50 °C at a 10 °C min−1 rate. Ex-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectra of pre-adsorbed CHB over samples were recorded using a BRUKER TENSOR II spectrometer equipped with an MCT narrow-band detector. First, 50 mg self-supporting sample wafer was soaked in a dichloromethane solution containing CHB for two days and then dried at 25 °C under vacuum for 12 h. Afterwards, the wafer was purged with an Ar gas flow of 50 mL·min−1 at 50 ℃ for 4 h, and then series of DRIFT spectra of CHB pre-adsorbed were collected under O2/N2 mixture gas (v/v,5:95) at different temperatures. 2.3 Catalytic oxidation reactions Liquid phase oxidation of CHB was conducted in a three-necked flask (50 mL) with a magnetic stirrer and a condenser, where the catalyst (20 mg) and CHB (10 mL) were charged. When the temperature of the reactant was heated to a set temperature under air atmosphere, the oxygen was fed into the flask at a certain flow rate. The oxidation was initiated with continuous stirring. After the reaction, liquid products were quantitatively analyzed by a liquid chromatograph (Shimadzu LC-20 CE) equipped with a GIST C18-AQ column using a UV detector (wavelength: 210 nm), where the mobile phase was a mixture of acetonitrile and ultrapure water with a volume ratio of 65:35. Meanwhile, the concentration of peroxide product was determined by indirect iodometric titration. In the case, CHBPH product reacted with saturated KI to generate elemental iodine, and the elemental iodine was further titrated with a standard Na2S2O3 solution. The catalyst was recovered by centrifugation and washed with ethanol for several times. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural analysis of samples Fig. 1A shows XRD patterns of different CuMnAl-LDH precursors. For CuMnAl-LDH-1.5 and CuMnAl-LDH-2, series of characteristic (003), (006), (012), (015), (018) diffractions of hydrotalcite-like phase (JCPDS No. 54-1030) can be observed, indicative of the feature of well-crystallized layered structure [24,25]. In the case of CuMnAl-LDH-1 with the higher Mn content, however, all diffractions are remarkably reduced, due to the distortion of laminate structure, mainly attributable to unstable Jahn-Teller effect due to the oxidation of Mn2+to Mn3+ ions during the synthesis of LDH precursors. Fig. 1B shows XRD patterns of different NC-CuMnO samples. It is worth noting that LDH phase completely disappears in all cases, owing to the collapse of the layered structure. For CuMnO-1.5 sample, only CuAlMnO4 phase (JCPDS No. 43-0285) is observed. In the cases of NC-CuMnO samples, in addition to weak diffractions related to CuAlMnO4 phase, intense characteristic diffraction peaks assignable to metallic copper (JCPDS No. 04-0836) and CuO (JCPDS No. 44-0706) phases can be discerned, indicative of the occurrence of the reduction of copper species upon high-temperature calcination of CuMnAl-LDH/melamine mixture under inert atmosphere. It demonstrates that the introduction of melamine in catalyst mixture precursors can facilitate the deep reduction of cationic Cu species to metallic Cu0 phase. However, no diffraction peaks of crystalline manganese oxides or alumina can be detected in NC-CuMnO samples, probably attributable to their highly dispersed or amorphous character. In this case, amorphous Al2O3 can serve as the dispersant favorable for the dispersion of active Cu and Mn species, probably promoting the oxidation of CHB to some extent. Fig. 2a-c presents SEM images of two representative CuMnO-1.5 and NC-CuMnO-1.5 samples. It is observed that two samples show a three-dimensional stacked aggregates composed of plenty of uniform nanosheets. Compared to that for CuMnO-1.5, the size of nanosheets for NC-CuMnO-1.5 decreases, indicative of the improved dispersion of NC-CuMnO-1.5. Further, the microstructure of NC-CuMnO-1.5 was characterized by TEM observations. As illustrated in Fig. 3d-f, the sheet-like microstructure can be clearly observed. Meanwhile, many small nanoparticles (NPs) with a size of 15–20 nm are well distributed over the surface, and the lattice fringes of 0.209 nm corresponding to the (111) crystal plane of metallic Cu0 can be discerned on the surface. And, an about 0.3 nm-thick encapsulation layer can be observed over the partial surface of NPs, probably attributable to the formation of NC overlayer on NPs. HAADF-STEM-EDX elemental mapping images of NC-CuMnO-1.5 (Fig. 2g-h) further reveal that six Cu, Mn, Al, C, N, and O elements are distributed homogeneously over the surface. Interestingly, the positions of C and N elements are basically consistent with those of Cu and Mn elements, reflecting the intimate contact of Cu and Mn species with NC layers. Such NC overlayers likely change the surrounding environments of CuMnO substrate in NC-CuMnO samples. Accordingly, compared to that of CuMnO-1.5 ( Table 1), specific surface areas of NC-CuMnO samples are lower, which may be due to the blocking of partial pores on the particle surface by NC overlayers. In order to investigate the redox properties of different CuMn-based samples, H2-TPR characterization was performed. As shown in Fig. 3, a broad and asymmetric consumption profile of hydrogen in the range of 100–400 °C can be divided into two contributions: the low-temperature small peak centered at 185–239 °C associated with the reduction of highly dispersed Cu2+ species and the high-temperature prominent peak centered at 240–291 °C associated with the reduction of Cu2+ and Mn4+/Mn3+ species in bulk. With either the introduction of NC or the increase in the Cu:Mn molar ratio, the high-temperature reduction shifts to higher temperatures, which may be assignable to the enhanced interactions between Cu and Mn species, as well as the rapid reduction of a large number of Cu species due to the introduction of melamine during the precursor calcination. Correspondingly, in the formed NC-CuMnO samples, a large amount of Cu2+ has been reduced, thus leading to the increased reduction temperature of H2-TPR curves. In order to study surface chemical and electronic structures of CuMn-based samples, XPS characterization was implemented. As displayed in Fig. 4A, two signals at about 932.5 and 934.7 eV in the fine Cu 2p spectra of CuMnO-1.5 are associated with CuB 2+ in CuO and CuA 2+ species located in the structure of CuAlMnO4 phase [26], respectively. Meanwhile, a weak Cu 2p3/2 signal at about 930.8 eV may be assignable to Cu+ species [27], as further proven by Cu LMM Auger spectra. As shown in Fig. 4B, a peak related to Cu+ species appears at 916.6 eV. In the cases of NC-CuMnO samples, the shape of Cu 2p3/2 peak is obviously different from that for CuMnO-1.5, due to the significant difference in the chemical composition, the near environment of copper species, and the structure of crystalline phases. Herein, the asymmetrical Cu 2p3/2 signal can be divided into three contributions, which are assignable to Cu0/Cu+ (∼932.4 eV), CuB 2+ (∼933.4 eV), and CuA 2+ (934.8–935.1 eV) species, respectively. Due to the close binding energies of Cu0 and Cu+ species, XPS results cannot be used to discriminate the assignment of Cu+ and Cu0. It is noted from Fig. 4B that the broad and asymmetric Cu LMM Auger spectra reveal the coexistence of Cu2+, Cu+, and Cu0 species in NC-CuMnO samples [28], despite the difference in the binding energies of three kinds of Cu species among samples. It further confirms that the redox process between copper species and melamine can facilitate the reduction of Cu2+ species upon high-temperature calcination. Noticeably, in the cases of NC-CuMnO samples, kinetic energies of Cu species present a gradually decreasing trend with the content of Cu, which is attributable to the enhanced interaction between Cu species and NC component (as also evidenced by the following N 1 s XPS results). Compared to that for CuMnO-1.5, the higher concentration of Cu (0) or Cu (I) species for NC-CuMnO samples should be assignable to the reducing effect of NC component. Obviously, higher surface Cu+/(Cu0 + Cu+ + Cu2+) ratios (0.17–0.26) on NC-CuMnO samples are attained (Table 1), compared to that on the CuMnO (0.15). Based on above XRD and XPS results, it is inferred that such Cu+ species may exist in the form of M-O-Cu+-like structures (M=Mn3+, Al3+, Cu2+) at the interface between CuAlMnO4 or CuO and metallic copper particles in NC-CuMnO samples owing to the enhanced metal-oxide interactions [29], probably forming more stable interfacial Cu+ sites. Such M-O-Cu+-like structures may easily facilitate the adsorption of CHB through electron-deficient Cu+ species as Lewis acidic sites interacting with the benzene ring in CHB, probably improving the catalytic activity of NC-CuMnO in the oxidation of CHB. In the fine Mn 2p spectra (Fig. 4C), the asymmetric Mn 2p3/2 signal can be deconvoluted into three peaks at about 640.2–640.6, 641.7–642.1, and 643.8–644.3 eV, respectively, which are associated with Mn2+, Mn3+, and Mn4+ species [30]. Interestingly, Mn species are mainly present in the form of Mn3+ species, further confirming the occurrence of redox process between Cu2+ and Mn2+ species in LDH precursors upon high-temperature calcination. In addition, in the cases of CuMnO samples, surface Mn2+/Mn3+ ratio gradually increases in the order: NC-CuMnO-2 (0.463) < CuMnO-1.5 (0.475) < NC-CuMnO-1 (0.677) < NC-CuMnO-1,5 (0.768) (Table 1). In our case, despite the formation of Mn4+-containing species, the reduction of Mn3+-containing species in calcined LDHs by NC component can lead to the loss of lattice oxygen in the CuAlMnO4 component with major Mn3+ ions and thus the formation of oxygen vacancies according to the following equation: Mn3+–O2-–Mn3+ + NC→ Mn2+–Ov–Mn2+ (Ov: oxygen vacancy). Correspondingly, for CuMn samples, the larger amount of Mn2+–Ov–Mn2+ defect structures may be related to the higher surface Mn2+/Mn3+ ratio. In above cases, the presence of surface defective oxygen vacancies, which may be conducive to the adsorption of molecular oxygen and thus the generation of surface reactive oxygen species during the oxidation [31,32]. As shown in Fig. 5A, in the O 1 s spectra of CuMn-based samples, two or three fitted peaks are assignable to the lattice oxygen species (OI, 530.0–531.1 eV), surface adsorbed oxygen species on oxygen vacancies (O2 - or O-) (OII, 531.5–532.3 eV), or oxygen species in adsorbed H2O or surface -C-OH and CO groups (OIII, 533.1 eV) [33–35], respectively. Compared to those for CuMnO-1.5, O1s signals for NC-CuMnO samples shift to higher binding energies, indicative of the enhanced electron interactions between oxygen atoms and adjacent electron-deficient Cu and Mn ions. Meanwhile, compared to other samples, NC-CuMnO-1.5 presents a higher OII/OI intensity ratio of 0.692 (Table 1), reflecting the generation of more oxygen vacancies. In above cases, high-temperature calcination of LDH/melamine mixture under inert atmosphere can easily result in the removal of the lattice oxygen in Mn-containing oxides and thus the formation of defective Mn2+–Ov–Mn2+ structures, consistent with above Mn 2p XPS results. As shown in Fig. 5B, three deconvoluted C 1 s peaks are associated with C-C or CC groups (CI, 284.6 eV), CN or C-OH groups (CII, 286.3 eV), and CO groups (CIII, 288.8 eV) [36,37], respectively. Meanwhile, for NC-CuMnO samples, there are two or three deconvoluted N 1 s peaks at about 397.5, 398.1–398.5, and/or 399.3 eV (Fig. 5C), respectively, which belong to pyridinic N atoms, pyrrolic N atoms, and/or graphitic N atoms [38]. Noticeably, compared to those reported in the literature, all N species present lower binding energies, which stems from the enhanced interactions between N-containing component and CuMnO matrix. Therefore, the above results confirm the generation of NC overlayers on NC-CuMnO samples, consistent with above HAADF-STEM-EDX and element analysis results (Table 1). Further, EPR was used to analyze the surface oxygen vacancies and environments of metal ions in CuMn-based samples. Fig. 6A presents a symmetrical signal at g = 2.018, which is associated with unpaired electrons at surface oxygen vacancies for three NC-CuMnO samples [39,40]. Additionally, the quantitative analysis of oxygen vacancies demonstrates that the quantity of oxygen vacancies decreases gradually from NC-CuMnO-1.5 to NC-CuMnO-1 and NC-CuMnO-2 (Fig. 6B). In the case of CuMnO-1.5 (Fig. 6C), only a weak and broad signal between 3500 and 3800 Guess associated with Cu2+ ions in tetrahedral CuO (CuB 2+) and octahedral environments (CuA 2+) in CuMnAlO4 can be observed [41], in good line with above XRD and XPS results. Based on above XPS and EPR results, it can be concluded that either the incorporation of NC component or the proper Cu:Mn molar ratio may trigger the formation of more surface oxygen vacancies on NC-CuMnO samples. It is well-known that molecular oxygen is easily adsorbed at surface oxygen vacancies, thereby leading to the filling of oxygen vacancy by one oxygen atom, accompanied by the formation of adsorbed oxygen species [42,43]. In the present NC-CuMnO catalyst system, the generation of large quantities of surface oxygen vacancies may be conducive to adsorption and activation of oxygen molecules during CHB oxidation to generate more surface oxygen species, probably accelerating the oxidation of CHB. Meanwhile, surface M-O pairs (M=Cu, Mn) with the negatively charged lattice oxygen atom on the catalyst may interact with the partially positively charged hydrogen atom from the cyclohexyl tertiary carbon in CHB [44,45], thereby activating the C–H bond, which may promote the formation of extremely active carbon-centered radicals (C6H5-C6H10·) and thus final CHBHP product during oxidation of CHB. 3.2 Catalytic oxidation activity of CuMn-based catalysts The catalytic performance of different CuMn-based catalysts in the oxidation of CHB was evaluated at 120 °C. In the absence of any catalysts, only a 3.2 % CHB conversion is attained ( Table 2). And, pristine Al2O3 only delivers a 3.5 % CHB conversion, indicating that Al2O3 cannot catalyze the oxidation of CHB. As shown in the Fig. 7 and Table 2, after 12 h of reaction, pure g-C3N4, CuO and MnO2 only achieve about 2.5 %, 6.5 %, and 8.6 % CHBHP yield, respectively. In the present catalytic oxidation system, 1-phenylcyclohexanol and hexanophenone were detected as main by-products. Meanwhile, compared to single metal oxides (CuO and MnO2) and CuMnO-1.5, all NC-CuMnO catalysts exhibit better catalytic activity with higher CHB conversions and CHBHP selectivities. Especially, NC-CuMnO-1.5 exhibits the best catalytic activity with a 42.3 % CHBHP selectivity at 39.0 % CHB conversion. However, neither lower Cu:Mn molar ratio nor higher Cu:Mn molar ratio is conducive to the conversion of CHB to CHBHP. However, CHBHP selectivities over NC-CuMnO catalysts are relatively lower than the homogeneous NHPI system [5], which is probably due to the easy decomposition of CHBHP product adsorbed on catalysts. Further, we studied the effects of reaction operating parameters on the oxidation of CHB over the NC-CuMnO-1.5 catalyst. As shown in Fig. 8A, both CHB conversion and CHBHP selectivity present an increasing trend with the reaction time up to 12 h. After reaction for 12 h, the CHB conversion reaches 39.0 % and the CHBHP selectivity is 42.3 %. After prolonging the reaction to 14 h, the conversion almost keeps unchanged but the CHBHP selectivity is decreased to 30.9 %, attributable to the formation of more 1-phenylcyclohexanol and hexanophenone by-products originating from the decomposition of CHBHP. The influence of reaction temperature on the CHB oxidation was explored between 90 and 130 °C (Fig. 8B). The CHB conversion gradually increases with the reaction temperature. Especially, when the temperature is elevated from 110° to 130°C, the conversion is remarkably improved from 27.5 % to 47.7 %, demonstrating the promotional effect of reaction temperature on the oxidation process. Meanwhile, the CHBHP selectivity shows a rapidly increasing trend with the reaction temperature elevated to 120 °C, Notably, the CHBHP selectivity is dramatically reduced at 130 °C, owing to the complete decomposition of CHBHP formed. The influence of the flow rate of oxygen on the oxidation process was also investigated (Fig. 8C). As the flow rate of oxygen increases from 10 to 25 mL/min, the conversion of CHB gradually decreases from 45.7 % to 39.0 %. Further increase in the flow rate of oxygen inversely leads to the increased conversion. However, the CHBHP selectivity has a convex change and reaches the maximum at the oxygen flow rate of 20 mL/min. It suggests that the higher flow rate of oxygen is conducive to the improvement of the concentration of oxygen in reaction solution, thus promoting the occurrence of side reactions, i.e., deep oxidation of CHBHP. The stability of the NC-CuMnO-1.5 catalyst was tested at 120 °C (Fig. 8D). The CHB conversion and the CHBHP selectivity are only decreased by about 0.8 % and 1.2 % after five successive runs. Such excellent structural stability of the catalyst should stem from the protection effect of surface NC overlayer covering CuMnO matrix, thereby inhibiting the structural change of the catalyst during oxidation reaction. Further, as shown in Fig. S1, XPS results of recovered NC-CuMnO-1.5 catalyst reveal that surface chemical states of Cu and Mn elements remain almost unchanged in comparison to the fresh catalyst, indicative the structural stability of the catalyst. As presented in Fig. 2F, the presence of the thin NC overlayer (∼0.3 nm thickness) over CuMnO particles may prevent active Cu and Mn species from dissolution, and migration during the oxidation, thus restraining the leaching of active species. Therefore, in this regard, surface NC overlayer on catalysts could protect surface structures of catalysts during the oxidation to some extent. 3.3 Analysis of Reaction mechanism For the oxidation of CHB, the strong adsorption of CHB substrate on CuMn-based catalysts can favor the activation of CHB. Therefore, TPD experiments of CHB (CHB-TPD) pre-adsorbed on different catalysts were performed ( Fig. 9). Noticeably, a broad desorption region in the range of 75–400 °C may be associated with the desorption of CHB adsorbed at surface electron-deficient cationic metal sites acting as Lewis acid sites. This is because the benzene ring in CHB may be easily adsorbed on Lewis acid sites through the delocalized π-bonding effect [46]. Compared to other catalysts, NC-CuMnO-1.5 presents a much higher area of desorption peak, along with the higher temperature of desorption peak (208 °C), suggesting that the proper interactions between Cu and Mn can promote the chemical adsorption of CHB substrate. Further, in order to get insight into the activity of CuMn-based catalysts, the ex-situ DRIFT analysis of CHB pre-adsorbed on two representative CuMnO-1.5 and NC-CuMnO-1.5 catalysts under the O2/N2 mixture flow (5:95, v/v) was implemented at different temperatures ( Fig. 10). For NC-free CuMnO-1.5 catalyst, there are several weak bands in the range of 3050–2820 cm−1, which are associated with the C-H stretching vibration bands for adsorbed CHB or derived compounds [47,48]. Meanwhile, an intense vibration band of CC bond in the benzene ring can be detected at about 1520 cm−1. Notably, four vibration bands of hydroxyl group (3747, 3530, 3350, and 3233 cm−1) and a weak bending vibration band of OOH group (1335 cm−1) appear at 60 °C, suggestive of the generation of surface hydrogen peroxide species due to the occurrence of surface oxidation of CHB absorbed [49,50]. In addition, two weak carbonyl vibration bands (1700 and 1620 cm−1) [51,52], a weak C-O vibration band (1070 cm−1) [53,54], and two weak O-O vibration bands (1070, 909 cm−1) [55,56] can be observed. It implies that gaseous oxygen molecule can be activated to form surface-active superoxide species (O2 -) and thus adsorbed CHB may be oxidized into CHBHP. Interestingly, with the elevated temperature from 60 to 120 °C, bands associated with the hydroxyl group are gradually reduced. Further increase in the adsorption temperature results in the enhanced bands of hydroxyl and carbonyl groups, as well as OOH and C-O groups. The above results imply that surface newly formed CHBHP species may easily decompose into carbonyl- and hydroxyl-containing species (e.g., 1-phenyl cyclohexanol and hexanophenone) at higher temperatures. These carbonyl- and hydroxyl-containing species adsorbed on the surface can continue to accumulate with the elevated temperature. Compared to those for CuMnO-1.5, surface hydroxyl vibration bands for NC-CuMnO-1.5 catalyst show a distinct change. Notably, hydroxyl and C-O vibration intensities present the sightly enhanced trend with the elevated temperature from 60 to 160 °C. Further increasing the temperature to 180 °C leads to the weakened hydroxyl vibrations and enhanced O-O vibration (1070 cm−1). It demonstrates that elevated temperatures can promote the activation of oxygen molecule and thus the formation of oxidative products. Meanwhile, bands of C-H and CO groups almost keep unchanged. It suggests that CHB can be more strongly adsorbed on the NC-CuMnO-1.5 catalyst through the interaction of the benzene ring in CHB and further oxidized to CHBHP by active oxygen species formed at oxygen vacancies. Interestingly, compared to that for CuMnO-1.5, the decomposition of surface newly formed CHBHP for NC-CuMnO-1.5 occurs at higher temperature, suggestive of the better CHBHP selectivity in the oxidation of CHB, along with the weak carbonyl vibration at higher temperatures and intense hydroxyl vibrations below 180 °C. Therefore, during surface oxidation of CHB, the intensity of CHBHP species formed on the surface of NC-CuMnO-1.5 is higher than that on the CuMnO-1.5, reflecting that the presence of abundant multivalent Cu and Mn ions and oxygen vacancies may play key promotional roles in the selective oxidation of CHB to CHBHP. According to the results of catalytic reactions (Table 2), NC-CuMnO-1.5 exhibited better catalytic performance than CuMnO-1.5, because NC-CuMnO-1.5 possesses more abundant amount of multivalent Cu and Mn ions and oxygen vacancies. However, the difference in the in-situ FTIR spectra between both catalysts is not remarkable, probably due to different sampling and analysis techniques from actual liquid oxidation reaction. Despite this, in-situ FTIR results can reveal the easy occurrence of CHB oxidation on the surface of CuMn-based catalysts. To attain further information on the CHB oxidation, a small amount of TBHP as the initiator (0.1 mL, 70 % aqueous solution) also was added into the reaction system. As presented in Fig. S2, over the NC-CuMnO-1.5, the addition of TBHP leads to the increased CHB conversion and CHBHP selectivity with the reaction time prolonging from 0.5 to 10 h, in comparison to those when only using molecular oxygen. Accordingly, a high CHBHP selectivity of 41.0 % is obtained at 42.8 % conversion after a reaction of 12 h. In addition, with the addition of a small amount of benzoquinone (0.1 g) as the radical scavenger, a quite low conversion of about 4.3 % is attained without the formation of CHBHP in the case of using molecular oxygen after 12 h of reaction (Table 2). Therefore, it can be confirmed that the present oxidation of CHB obeys a free radical reaction route. In the course of oxidation, concentrations of Cu and Mn in reaction solution analyzed by ICP-ES after 12 h are about 0.4 and 0.3 ppm, respectively, indicating a negligible Cu and Mn leaching from the NC-CuMnO-1.5 catalyst. In addition, the reaction was hot filtered to remove the NC-CuMnO-1.5 catalyst after a reaction time of 2 h (20 % conversion). Subsequently, a further reaction without the catalyst was continued. After 12 h, CHB conversion almost keeps unchanged under the same conditions, strongly indicating that the present reaction should proceed mostly on the surface of heterogeneous catalysts. Based on above research results and related literature, a possible mechanism of CHB oxidation to form CHBHP over present NC-CuMnO catalysts is proposed in Scheme 2. The peroxidation of CHB obeys a typical free radical reaction route involving the following processes. First, CHB is rapidly adsorbed on the surface of catalysts, especially at highly dispersed M-O-Cu+-like structures. Meanwhile, molecular oxygen is adsorbed at oxygen vacancies around metal sites to form active oxygen species (O2 −). Therefore, for NC-CuMnO catalysts, the formation of favorable highly dispersed electron-deficient Cu+ and Mn3+/4+ ions and abundant surface oxygen vacancies can facilitate the adsorption and activation of CHB and oxygen molecules. Second, the hydrogen atom from the cyclohexyl tertiary carbon in CHB can interact with negatively charged lattice oxygen atoms bound to Cu and Mn ions [57], thus weakening the C–H bond on the cyclohexyl tertiary carbon of CHB to decompose into CHB tertiary carbon species (R·). Third, on NC-CuMnO catalysts, the bonding between active oxygen species and CHB tertiary carbon species leads to the generation of CHB tertiary carbon peroxide free radial (ROO·). Finally, ROO·free radial can further abstract the hydrogen atom from another CHB to produce target CHBHP product. However, the further decomposition of CHBHP product adsorbed on catalysts easily leads to the formation of free radial (RO·). Correspondingly, the interaction between RO·radical and CHB may generate main 1-phenylcyclohexanol by-product. In addition, the β-C–C cleavage of RO·radical can generate another hexanophenone by-product. As a result, the improved adsorption–activation of CHB and oxygen molecules on the NC-CuMnO-1.5 catalyst significantly contribute to a superior catalytic activity in the oxidation of CHB to those of other CuMn-based catalysts and single metal oxides. Finally, it should be noted that the CHB oxidation technique is still in its infancy and many shortcomings and fundamental and technical challenges, such as poor product selectivity, the formation of large amounts of 1-phenylcyclohexanol and hexanophenone by-products (maximum selectivity reaches ∼25 and ∼ 5 %, respectively), and difficult separation and purification of CHBHP product, remain currently. Therefore, it is still important to continuously develop high-performance metal-based catalysts with enhanced efficiency and set up advanced production techniques. In general, the present study provides a convenient large-scale catalyst preparation method of highly stable CuMn-based catalysts derived from LDH precursors, thus giving great potential for the innovation of the advanced catalyst candidate applied in the liquid-phase oxidation of CHB in the future. 4 Conclusions To sum up, we developed new, low-cost, and environment-friendly NC-combined CuMn-based catalysts for the oxidation of CHB to form CHBHP. It was shown that the redox effect between Cu and Mn ions, as well as the introduction of melamine, promoted the formation of multivalent Cu and Mn ions and thus induced the creation of favorable Cu-O-Mn structures and abundant defective oxygen vacancies. As-fabricated NC-CuMnO catalysts exhibited higher activities and CHBHP selectivities, compared to NC-free CuMnO catalyst and single metal oxides (CuO and MnO2). Especially, NC-CuMnO catalyst bearing a 1:1 Cu:Mn molar ratio delivered the highest activity in the oxidation of CHB to CHBHP. According to series of structural characterizations, it was demonstrated that favorable multivalent Cu and Mn species and abundant surface oxygen vacancies promoted the adsorption of CHB and oxygen molecules on NC-CuMnO catalysts. Moreover, NC-CuMnO catalysts possessed high structural stability, attributable to the inhibiting effect of surface NC overlayers on the change of surface structures during the oxidation. The present study offers more insights into the origin of surface-active structures of catalysts in the oxidation of CHB, thus shedding light on the rational design of metal-based catalysts for advanced catalysis processes. coredata.dc:description: In this work, we fabricated nitrogen-doped carbon (NC)-combined CuMn-based catalysts derived from layered double hydroxide and melamine mixture precursor and further explored their activity in the aerobic oxidation of cyclohexylbenzene (CHB) to produce cyclohexylbenzene-1-hydroperoxide (CHBHP) using molecular oxygen as the oxidant. Series of structural characterizations demonstrated that multivalent Cu and Mn species and abundant surface defective oxygen vacancies could form in catalysts, due to comprehensive redox processes between Cu and Mn atoms upon high-temperature calcination of precursors under inert atmosphere, as well as the promotional effect of melamine added on the reduction of metal ions. As-fabricated NC-combined CuMn catalyst bearing a 1:1 Cu:Mn molar ratio showed a higher catalytic oxidation activity, in comparison to other NC-decorated CuMn-based catalysts, NC-free CuMn-based one, and pure single metal oxides (i.e., CuO, MnO2). It was revealed that the presence of favorable multivalent Cu and Mn ions and abundant oxygen vacancies was conducive to the effective adsorption and activation of CHB and oxygen molecules, thus accelerating the selective oxidation of CHB to form CHBHP. Moreover, surface NC overlayer on catalysts could protect surface structures of catalysts during the oxidation. The present study provides deep understanding of the roles of surface-active metal species and oxygen vacancies of CuMn-based catalysts for efficient oxidation of CHB to form CHBHP.
coredata.dc:title: The promotional roles of multivalent metal ions and oxygen vacancies on nitrogen-doped carbon-combined CuMn-based catalysts for cyclohexylbenzene oxidation
